name: Pac-Tracer
description:
This piece was commissioned by the MIT Center for Art, Science & Technology (CAST) for the Generative Unfoldings exhibiton. Pac-Tracer is a programatic animation that examines the elegance and liveliness of the original Pac-Man AI, developed in 1980, by following the paths of Pac-Man and the four ghosts through an extruded 3D maze. Pac-Man’s AI represents some of the earliest and still most compelling work in games AI, with simple rules evoking the sense that each ghost has its own personality and own predispositions for mischief.

The rules that define the ghost movement are not truly adversarial: rather, they are about spatial desires. Each ghost has a place they want to be relative to Pac-Man and their fellow ghosts. This project allows those desires to play out unfettered by concerns about gamestate, or for that matter, any human interloper. By tracing those paths through the maze, the idiosyncrasies and personalities emerging from those rules become clear. What was a hunt now looks more like a waltz of attraction.

To compliment the web-app, I created a series of plotter drawings from frames of the animation.

You can view Pac-Tracer on the Generative Unfoldings website.

name: Twisty Tunnels
description:
This quick-reflex pixel-art game was created as a demo game for the Indie Maker Syndicate Jam Jam Revolution, which I helped to run. It was originally designed to be played using the custom hardware that all participants built for the jam, but I later released it as a keyboard-controlled game.

You can play this game for free in-browser here.

Although it takes strong visual influence from the Pico-8 Fantasy Console, it was built using P5.js. This was an opportunity to use many of the visual techniques I had developed writing tweet-length visual programs in the #tweetcart and #p5t hashtags.

The audio was created by Jay Ackley.

name: Pen Plotter Art
description:
I create and sell pen-plotter drawings made using an AxiDraw V3 plotter.

A complete list of my plotter art can be found in the Plotter heading of this portfolio.

The code to generate these drawings is written by me, and in most cases allows for variations such that no two drawings will be the same. All of the drawings are written in C++ using openFrameworks and my own open-source G-Code library.

These drawings are done using archival quality ink on ph-neutral paper.

Available drawings can be purchased from my store.

name: MTG Plotter Prints
description:
While quarantining, I used my AxiDraw Pen Plotter to print a proxy Magic The Gathering deck to play with friends over webcam.

To translate the complex art in the game into instructions my plotter could read, I created a suite of tools in openFrameworks that allowed me to break the image up into layers and apply different filters (also designed by me). The layout and borders were programmed from scratch, but drew inspiration from the source cards.

The library I made to convert openFrameworks drawings into gcode is freely available here.

The cards were primarily printed using Uni-ball metallic inks.

The complete collection can be seen on my Tumblr.
vid: Force of Will Plotter print Time-lapse from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Turf Wars
description:
My partner Jane Friedhoff and I were hired by Wasserman Media Group to license, “reskin,” and install our game Salmon Roll: The Upstream Team at the AT&T booth at the College Football Playoff Fan Central expo in New Orleans. This involved changing the visuals and some gameplay to have a football theme, and designing and creating new custom controllers for the game.

Chris Hernandez created the new sprites & Kyle Magocs fabricated the controllers.

name: Killipede Music Video
description:
I directed and animated this music video for the song Killipede by Dan Friel off his new album Fanfare. The video was written entirely in C++ using openFrameworks and makes heavy use of JPEG corruption.

I wrote a lengthy post about the creation of this video on my blog.

I also created the album cover for Fanfare using methods developped for the video.

name: Fanfare Album Cover
description: After creating the music video for Killipede for Dan Friel I used the same techniques to generate this image, which was used as the cover of his album Fanfare.

name: Maciavelli & Cheese Truck
description:
The Night Market is “a transient bazaar where one can encounter a variety of mysterious lounges, theaters, galleries, cafes, installations and other establishments, all situated within seemingly ordinary box trucks.”

In 2019 I helped create the Maciavelli & Cheese Truck, a brutal food truck that preyed on the worst impulses of man. The design was lead by Larissa Hayden.

In addition to creating the truck, I acted as the carnival barker, luring participants in and selecting a suitable "prince" in each group. That's me in the first pictrue. I wrote about the creation of the truck here.

The first image was taken by Tod Seelie for Gothamist.

name: Ziggurat of the Titan Beetle
description:
Ziggurat of the Titan Beetle is a four-player party rougelike where players must communicate and work together to beat dungeons. Despite striving towards a common goal, time pressure and shared resources make it easy to accidentaly step on each other's toes.

This game was created as an exclusive reward for backers of the Wonderville Kickstarter campaign.

Sprites and logo by Chris Hernandez.

The Titan Beetle is a real creature and the largest known species of beetle.

name: Circumnavigators
description:
Created in collaboration with Juno Morrow, Circumnavigators is a physical arcade game where players must run around a circular strip of LEDs attempting to keep their glowing dot safe. Tapping the arcade buttons along the top moves the obstacles (represented by different color bars). Players must physically keep up with their dot and are encouraged to sabotage other players.

The game was initially created at Death By Audio Arcade’s Alt.Ctrl Jam where it was built into a garbage can. Andy and Juno have since built a proper housing for it and it has been shown at Caveat, Secret Project Robot, MAGFest 2019 & the Smithsonian American Art Museum Arcade in 2019.

First photo by Nick Santaniello.

Video by Juno Morrow.
vid: Circumnavigators from Juno Morrow on Vimeo.

name: Arcade Truck
description:
The Night Market is “a transient bazaar where one can encounter a variety of mysterious lounges, theaters, galleries, cafes, installations and other establishments, all situated within seemingly ordinary box trucks.” Years after I helped with my first truck, I returned with Death By Audio Arcade to build an arcade installation in a truck.

The truck featured three arcade games, hanging light art, and a piece of video art projected across the entire truck to create a sensory-overload imagined alternate future arcade.

You can read more about the installation on my blog.

Chris Hernandez, Allen Riley & Dustin Long of DBAA also helped design and execute the truck.

Photos by Emi Spicer.

name: Chalice of Brevium
description:
Chalice of Brevium is an experimental roguelike created while following along with a game-a-week class being taught by my my colleague at LIU, Ramiro Corbetta. Players must work together to push the Chalice to the portal.

The board state is shared by all players and it is interacted with one user at a time. Although they can practice as long as they’d like, each user gets only a single, 10-second chance to advance the game. After this they are locked out until the current board is beaten. Furthermore, players must use one of three classes, all of which are required to advance and protect the chalice, forcing them to work together (or fail).

It can be played for free at andymakes.com/chalice.

name: Pivop
description:
Pivop is a small, one-button arcade game about a swinging head. It was created in one week while following along with a game-a-week class being taught by my colleague at LIU, Ramiro Corbetta.

Pivop is free and can be played in the browser on Itch.io.

The art in the game was created using Doodle Studio 95 and the music was composed by me on a Pocket Operator Tonic.

name: A Place To Bury Strangers Pinball
description:
A Place To Bury Strangers Pinball is a custom pinball machine created by Death By Audio Arcade and themed around the NYC psychedelic rock band A Place To Bury Strangers.

The machine itself is a repurposed 1959 Gottlieb Mademoiselle that was gutted and rebuilt using modern technology, including a fog machine, strobe lights, lasers, and LED lighting.

Credits:
Hardware and Electronics: Mark Kleeb & Steve Litt
Software and Programming: Andy Wallace & Dustin Long
Playfield Artwork: Joe Jurewicz
Marquee Artwork: Preston Spurlock
Sound Design: Travis Johnson
Graphic Design: Chris Hernandez
Original Music and Video: A Place To Bury Strangers

A more detailed writeup can by found on the Death By Audio Arcade blog

First photo by Joe Ahearn
vid: <iframe width='700' height='450' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/u5J5mHw6u3s'></iframe>

name: The DreamBoxXx
description:
I worked with Death By Audio Arcade to create The DreamboxXx, a queer arcade machine that now lives at Dream House/Spectrum, a queer events space in Brooklyn. This arcade machine contains 9 games by local queer and trans developers created specifically for this hardware. I managed this project, working with Ayla Myers to curate and invite the participating devs. I also wrote the software that ran in the arcade machine to allow users to select their game and to make sure it would remain stable in a public space.

The games were later released by the devs as a bundle to raise money for the Sylvia Sylvia Rivera Law Project and Make The Road New York.

Photos by Walter Wlodarczyk.

A post about designing and building the launcher can be found on my blog.

name: Lost Wage Rampage
description:
Lost Wage Rampage by Jane Friedhoff is a fast, raucous, arcade driving game about what happens when two shopgirls find out their male coworkers have been paid more than them, and decide to steal back the difference. Lost Wage Rampage was made possible by a commission from the Peabody Essex Museum.

Jane Friedhoff did level design, game design, and general coding, Marlowe Dobbe did art and animation, and I created the procedual level generation framework.

The game can be played for free on the PEM website.

name: Nike NY vs NY Kiosk
description:
I developed the interface for an LED news-ticker that was mounted along the four walls of a kiosk for Nike’s NY VS NY exhibition basketball games over the summer of 2018.

My openFrameworks app pulled information about the games from a database and converted it into a format that could be used by the LED display. Nike later contracted me again to update the project for the 2018 World Series.

name: Triple Tone Curious Creature
description:
A mysterious lifeform is contacting us from deep in space.
It sings to us and desperately wants us to answer with the same song.

This game was created for Global Game Jam 2018 at LIU Post using a custom capacitive touch controller built on site. The game was written in openFrameworks and the controller uses an Arduino and an MPR121 capacitive touch sensor (and some tin foil).

Players attempt to combine wave forms to match the tone generated by the alien.

The game is available (in a keyboard controlled form) for free on Itch.

name: Urza's Dream Engine
description:
Urza's Dream Engine is a neural network art bot that generates original images in the style of card art from the Magic: The Gathering collectible card game. It was inspired by @RoboRosewater, another neural network that generates card text for the game. After gathering and cropping all existing art from the game (roughly 30,000 cards over the two decades that Magic has been in print), I broke the art down into sections based on the type of card it came from and allowed the bot to train for a week before asking it to generate images in the same style. These images were eventually used in combination with the RoboRosewater text to hold a tournament with entirely machine-generated cards.

The images created by the bot, as well as several downloads, including print-and-play cards are available under a Creative Commons license at the bottom of the project's page.

Urza's Dream Engine was created using this Tensorflow implementation of Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Networks by Taehoon Kim.

Photo by Lippe.

name: Bleep Space
description:
Bleep Space was inspired by playing with a friend’s Korg sequencer and the joy I found in creating music while exploring a device that I didn’t fully understand. Created in collaboration with local musician Dan Friel, Bleep Space is a sequencer toy for iOS, PC & Mac. Users tap the screen to add noisy samples to their sequence and watch as lively geometric animations accompany the sounds.

Bleep Space was a finalist at the 2017 IndieCade Festival and was shown at the Smithsonian American Art Museum Arcade in 2019.

In addition to the free digital release, I worked with Mark Kleback to create a tabletop installation to house the game, featuring light-up tactile buttons and a round screen. This device is currently touring different locations in New York and was debuted at the IndieCade festival in L.A..

More info at BleepSpace.com.
Development info here.
vid: Bleep Space Trailer from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Salmon Roll: The Upstream Team
description:
In the summer of 2017, Jane Friedhoff and I were commissioned to make an installation game for Play NYC, a games conference in NYC held in Terminal 5. We created Salmon Roll: The Upstream Team, a two player collaborative game with a five foot long custom controller based on the 1983 arcade game Ice Cold Beer (also the inspiration for TumbleSeed).

We also served as co-chairs of Installation Games for the conference and curated a collection of other installation games made for the event by local digital artists and game designers.

Salmon Roll was also shown at the Smithsonian American Art Museum Arcade in 2019.

Game by Andy Wallace and Jane Friedhoff.
Art by Diego Garcia
Photos by Jo Chiang

Brief write-up of our development process here.

name: Noise Snke
description:
Noise Snke is an experimental Snake game that plays with data mutability by writing its board state directly to the sound card. The harsh sound that it creates highlights the fact that to a computer, data has no intrinsic meaning and can be used for any purpose.

Noise Snke was shown in Korea in 2016 at the Busan Indie Connect Festival. Game and a write-up is available here.
vid: Noise Snke (turn down your volume) from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: TCG Proxy Gen
description:
TCG Proxy Gen & TCG Booster Gen are a set of tools which allow players and designers to print cards for trading card games such as Magic The Gathering. TCG Proxy Generator is a more user friendly, GUI based application that allows users to drag and drop card images to create ready-to-print proxy sheets. TCG Booster Gen is a more powerful tool which can be used to create full booster packs, either to test fan sets or to run proxy booster drafts. I made these tools to help facilitate Weird MTG, a series of tournaments and games I organize aimed at exploring unusual or overlooked aspects of Magic: The Gathering.

Both tools were made in openFrameworks and are available for free on itch.io.

name: Hungry Hungry Astronauts
description:
Death By Audio Arcade was commissioned by the meal replacement company Soylent to develop an arcade machine that featured their astronaut mascot. I designed an implemented an original 4-player Pac-Man-style game for the project.

The arcade cabinet was fabricated by Mark Kleback and Chris Hernandez created the art for the game and the arcade cabinet.

The arcade was playable for a few weeks in Solylent’s pop-up in L.A. and now occasionally pops up in unexpected places.

name: Drink Rink
description:
Drink Rink is a bar and a game platform created with fellow Death By Audio Arcade members Mark Kleback and K. Anthony Marefat. Drinks are placed in special coozies that are seen by the cameras in the bar and used as game pieces for the game projected up onto surface. The bar runs a collection ambient games and cycles between them. In 2018, several additional scenes that would react to hands or anything placed on the bar were added. The bar debuted at the Lwlvl chiptune festival in Brooklyn.

Some photos by Walter Wlodarczyk.

name: Genetic Combat
description:
This browser simulation attempts to create effective spaceship shooter AI using a genetic algorithm. The game itself is roughly based on Combat for the Atari 2600. When it starts, all ships are created with a completely randomized set of rules that govern their behavior. Once all of the ships in a given generation get a chance to compete, the ones that got the most kills (with a bonus for not dying themselves) are allowed to continue to the next generation and to have children. The children inherit the same set of behaviors that the parents had, but mutate them slightly: a value gets changed here and there, maybe a rule gets removed or a new one gets added. Even though these changes are random, over many generations the natural selection process selects for mutations that make them more effective pilots.

Full site here
Also avalaible on itch.io

name: Steam Users Don't Know What They Want
description:
This Chrome extension attempts make sense of Steam reviews by changing the text of any “do not recommend” review by a user who has played over 24 hours of the game to “I do not know what I want.”

Available for free on the Chrom Web Store.

name: ZipCalc!
description:
It’s the geolocative calculator of nobody's dreams! ZipCalc is a Hell Products and a joke about consumerism bought to its breaking point. It's a calculator that uses your phone's GPS to find your zip code and adds it to the result.

The app was also an elaborate ploy to sneak in an easter egg asking my amazing partner Jane to marry me (she said yes!).

You can download it for free on the iOS app store.

name: Terminal Town
description:
Terminal Town is a small, experimental puzzle that exists as a series of mysterious & anthropomorphized command line tools. Every executable is a person or a tool and every folder is a place.

Players are tasked with opening the chest (a command line tool) in the center of town, and must learn how use the files that inhabit the town. There is no way to cheat. Everything in the game is just a file on the computer and can be treated as such.

While some experience with the terminal is helpful, the game does not require anything intense, and acts as a fun way to learn about a powerful part of the computer that many users are unfamiliar with.

It is available for free (Mac only).

name: Satan.Dance
description:
Satan.Dance is a cut-up web toy that stitches one word clips from the 90s police propaganda film Law Enforcement Guide To Satanic Cults.

It was written in P5.js as part of a class I took at The School For Poetic Computation.

It can be viewed at satan.dance.

name: Intimate Codex
description:
Intimate Codex is an interactive non-linear text explorer that allows the user to traverse static text from a more first-person perspective. Books, poems, and any other texts fed into it are broken up into passages, and the user can move between these passages by typing a particular word on screen. After submitting that word, they are brought to a new passage that shares that word.

By providing connections between different passages (and even entirely different works) based on keywords and randomness, new narratives and meanings appear that can be vastly different from the original, linear stories.

Users are also encouraged to provide their own text, either from stories they like or their own original writing.

It can be downloaded for pay-what-you-want here

The overall experience was inspired by Her Story.
vid: Intimate Codex from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: The Easter Money
description:
The Easter Money is a low stakes gambling game designed by me & Jane Friedhoff for my family's 2016 Easter party. Your goal is to end the game with the most money cards (or at least as much as you started with).

The game is available for free as a print print-and-play in both color and b/w variants.

The illustrations on the color cards come from the New York Public Library's collection of public domain images.

name: Bloom Cave
description:
Bloom Cave is an endless cave-gardening sim created in 48 hours for Global Game Jam 2016 for the theme ”ritual”. Moving past the edge of a room will cause a new one to be created based on the runes in the crurrent garden. The runes are inscrutable, though, forcing the player to simply wander and enjoy.

It can be played for free here.

Music by Nathaniel Chambers.
vid: Bloom Cave, Global Game Jam 2016 from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: PARTICLE MACE
description:
PARTICLE MACE is a game for Windows, Mac and iOS that pays homage to classic space shooters, but replaces the typical guns with an unruly physics-based weapon. Players control a tiny ship in an extremely hostile universe, and must defend themselves as long as possible from enemy ships and asteroids using a collection of trash particles tethered to the ship. To survive, players must carefully navigate around the many hazards while building up momentum to swing their weapon into foes or other players.

Inspired by twitchy arcade classics old and new, PARTICLE MACE requires quick reflexes to stay alive, rewarding skilled players with high scores worth bragging about and giving new players a reason to hit restart. Graphically, the game uses abstracted visuals to create a striking play field combined with an entrancing procedural background.

More info at particlemace.com.
vid: PARTICLE MACE Trailer from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Extreme Exorcism
description:
Extreme Exorcism is best described as a mixture of Braid and Super Crate Box. With each ghost you kill, another takes its place. You’ve been given access to a multitude of devastating weapons to rid the spirits--the only problem is, they copy your every attack.

Extreme Exorcism was born out of a small window of time we had between projects at Golden Ruby Games and became our first multi-console release.

The game is available on Steam for PC and Mac as well as PS3, PS4, Xbox One and Wii U
vid: Extreme Exorcism Trailer from Golden Ruby Games on Vimeo.

name: Musclebound Glory
description:
Musclebound Glory is a card- and prop-based party game about channeling your inner 80s action hero and crafting the perfect kill line. Players hear a randomized action movie-style moment (including the villain being killed, the method of annihilation, and a twist), for which they must craft the perfect killer zinger. Players don berets, bandoliers, and Ray Bans to deliver their lines in style. The best line is decided by the group, and a new hero walks away from the explosion victorious, never turning back.

Musclebound Glory was shown at Come Out And Play 2014 in New York. We provided the deck and a carefully curated collection of props

Photo by Lia Bulaong

name: Hermit Crab In Space
description:
Originally created as part of the Sony-sponsored PlayStation Mobile jam at the first Indiecade East, Hermit Crab In Space is the third game by Golden Ruby Games. One part Star Fox, one part Minecraft, with a healthy dose of Captain Forever mixed in, Hermit Crab in Space won the IndieCade East GameJam in February 2013 and became a finalist at IndieCade the following year.

Players take the role of a hermit crab who has warped herself into the wrong sector and must cobble together a ship from the parts she blasts off her opponents. The game makes use of the touch screen and tactile buttons of the Sony Vita by allowing players to drag free-floating pieces to their ship and then select a button to activate them. This means that players create their ship and control scheme on the fly while playing.

Level and enemy design by Jane Friedhoff.

It is available on any PSM enabled device, but is intended to be played on the Vita. You can visit its PSM page here.
vid: Hermit Crab in Space - Official Trailer from Golden Ruby Games on Vimeo.

name: Worm Run
description:
You are Zeke Tallahassee, hapless space miner in the wrong place at the wrong time. Swipe on your touchscreen to move Zeke through an ever-changing labyrinth all while being chased by a blood-thirsty, gigantic space Worm.

This was our second title at Golden Ruby Games and was made available for iOS, Android, & Windows 8.

Our goal with this game was to create a control scheme for platformers that made sense for touch screens. We did this by adopting a gestural control scheme, rather than using clunky on-screen buttons, creating a tense, platforming experience actually designed for the device the game was being played on.

We also explored potential for a shared multiplayer experience that used iPhones as controllers when we ran a special four-person version of the game at the Gowanus Loft in Brooklyn.

A detailed description of how the procedural caves of Worm Run are created can be found here.
vid: Worm Run Updated Trailer from Golden Ruby Games on Vimeo.

name: Doodle Defense
description:
Doodle Defense is a tower defense game that explores drawing as a means for game interaction and play. Players draw mazes and towers on a whiteboard with regular dry erase markers to stop projected foes. The game received 150% backing on Kickstarter and has been featured on IndieGames.com, Engadget, PC World, Ubergizmo, FastCo Design, and many other publications. It went on to be shown at Come Out And Play San Francisco, SF MOMA and the Dublin Science Gallery.

The game uses a camera and a projector in conjunction with the whiteboard to create a unique platform for play. The code and system is all my own, written in openFrameworks. The code is open source and can be viewed here.

All art in the game was done by Michelle Belickis.

The game is available for free for whiteboard at doodledefense.com and for $2 on iPad.
vid: DoodleDefenseTrailer from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Find Me A Good One
description:
Find Me A Good One was created with Haitham Ennasr as our MFA thesis at Parsons The New School For Design, and was nominated as an IndieCade 2012 Finalist. It is available for free for PC or Mac here.

Find Me A Good One is a puzzle platformer that explores the sense of responsibility felt by players towards non-playing fictional characters. Although the brother in Find Me A Good One is clearly dependent on the player, it is up to the player to decide how much they want to help their sibling. While most games force the player to complete the task at hand in order to move on, Find Me A Good One allows the player to be diligent in their responsibility, or shirk it in order to further explore the dreamscape of the game. Because the system does not assign value to her actions, the player is left to judge their own actions and the effect they have on their virtual brother.

name: Destroy All Color
description: The first game we released at Golden Ruby Games, Destroy All Color! is a fast-paced puzzle game played by using the iPhone's camera to find and use colors in the player's environment to destroy blocks on screen. The color choosen is then used in the subsequent levels, getting progressively more difficult. This makes for a unique and interesting game mechanic that combines the real world around the player with the digital puzzle of the game.
vid: Destroy All Color! Trailer from Golden Ruby Games on Vimeo.

name: Chase No Face
description:
To shoot this video we programmed a series of masks in openFrameworks based on the face tracking code developed by Zach Lieberman and Daito Manabe using the FaceTracker library by Jason Saragih. No post-production effects were used: everything in the video was recorded live, using a hacked Kinect, a laptop, a projector and a DSLR camera. Some of the masks respond to movement and others respond to sound, creating an expressive outcome.

Bell is a Brooklyn-based independent musician.

Project team : Zach Lieberman (General direction, programming, video direction), Francisco Zamorano (Video direction, editing, programming), Andy Wallace (programming), Michelle Calabro (camera).

Photos and blurb by Francisco Zamorano
vid: Chase No Face / BELL from Francisco Zamorano on Vimeo.

name: Horse_ebooks Talker
description:
The Horse_ebooks Talker deals with the id of the internet in the form of Twitter spam-bot extraordinaire, Horse_ebooks. This Twitter account advertises its products, but avoids the spam filters by grabbing random snippets of text from across the internet to appear ”alive” and in the process creates a compelling Dadaist tapestry of text from across the internet. This project tries to put these words back in the mouths of people by providing an augmented reality for anybody who looks at it, assigning them a random tweet to appear in a word balloon above their head.

This piece was featured in Open Concept Gallery's Smart Multimedia Festival.

name: All Cyrax Wants To Do Is Dance
description:
This simple HTML5 game was created as an exercise to learn jQuery, which I felt like I really ought to know. It tells the touching story of a cybernetic ninja who just wants to get down.

It can be played here.

name: Broken Mirror
description:
Broken Mirror is a camera application made in openFrameworks for the iPhone and iPad that takes the incoming camera feed and breaks it apart into a pixelated and constantly moving mosaic. Users can control the degree of abstraction in the image.

The app is 99 cents on the iOS store.

name: Sound Balls
description:
Created as my first year final project at Parsons, Sound Balls is a non-traditional method of sound generation that blends digital and analog elements in the form of a new audio toy. By manipulating a set of smart balls, users convert real world action into a fluid sound-scape that affords play and exploration. The system as a whole has two unique modes of interaction: Free Form and Singing Bowl, and users learn the rules of these systems while interacting with the balls. The balls themselves have unique attributes in both their hardware and the way the information from them is converted into sound. The information is gathered from each ball by an implanted micro-controller and sent wirelessly to a computer where it is interpreted in order to create the sound.

Design Document: Here

Base Station Arduino Code: Here

Ball Transmitter Arduino Code: Here

Transmitter Wiring Diagram: Here

Receiver openFrameworks Code: Here

SuperCollider Code: Here
vid: Sound Balls from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: ASCII Filter
description:
Based on an example project by Ben Fry packaged with the Processing language, this program takes incoming video and converts it to a text output. Pixels from the original image are considered as a group, and each letter is chosen based on both its overall weight as well as how well the shape fits the pixel group.

Ben Fry's original required the use of color to show the image, but to have a filter that felt authentic to ASCII art, I wanted to create one that worked in simple black and white.

Processing Source Code: Here
vid: ASCII Video Filter from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Sisyphus.nes
description:
This collection of hacked Super Mario ROMs converts the game into retellings of three Greek myths. While Icarus is fairly straightforward, Prometheus and Sisyphus exploit systems within Mario to create games where the player can neither win nor die.

Prometheus is forced to collect an unavoidable mushroom before being struck by unavoidable bullets until he eventually reaches an inescapable chamber to wait while time runs out.

Sisyphus hacks a one-off looping level of the original game to create a mountain that the player continuously scales without ever progressing.

These ROM hacks were created in collaboration with Bree Chapin and Justin Blinder while we were at Parsons.

The ROMs can be downloaded here
vid: SuperSisyphusBros from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: The Cuddle Cave
description: I worked with Jane Friedhoff and Dustin Hoffman to create a truck for the Lost Horizons Night Market called the Cuddle Cave. The Cave consisted of over 150 Ikea pillows in the back of a U-Haul dressed up with satin sheets that could only be gotten to via crawling through a small dark tunnel. Those brave enough to enter were treated with calming music and a soft respite from the cold autumn night outside.

name: Star Gaze
description:
This unique side-scroller was created by me and Haitham Ennasr as a proof of concept for our thesis at Parsons, exploring how game mechanics can make players feel responsible for NPCs. The player must pick their brother up at a train station late at night. On their way, they are given the chance to gaze up at the heavens to populate the sparse environment with constellations. However, this consumes an unknown amount of time and causes the player to run the risk of being late. There is no definite good or bad ending, but we observed that players tended to attach emotional weight to this relatively mundane situation.

It can be played online here.

name: Bounce Box
description:
Bounce Box is a simple but compelling game with just one rule: to keep the balls in the box. With each hit, the colors of the game shift, and as more balls get added, the visuals change more rapidly and the game becomes more difficult.

Bounce Box is free on the iOS store.
vid: Bounce Box Trailer from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Fever Karaoke
description:
While interning with Eyebeam fellow David Jimison, I created animations and worked on the code of his project, Fever Karaoke. The piece was presented in a karaoke bar setting, but after participants selected a song, they were presented with mad-lib style word replacements, which would alter the words of the song as they sang.

These animations were projected behind the players and danced along with them. The animations are modular and code-driven so that they could be swapped and rearranged easily.

name: Isabelle, Poppy & Bling
description:
As I was finishing up my undergrad degree, I was approached by musician Justin Braun, to create a music video to promote his new album, Relays From Home. After listening to the song a few times, though, I thought the music was better suited for a game.

The game was made in Flash uses a collage style and is split into three major sections, each of which takes inspiration from and is directly affected by the music.

This game was a Browser Game Pick at indieClick.com and was featured in Gamasutra's article Best of Indie Games: Falling Head Over Heels For Art Games.

It can be played for free on Kongregate.
vid: Isabelle Poppy & Bling Gameplay (2009) from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Roving
description: This music video was created in Flash for the pirate puppet rock opera, Jollyship The Whiz-Bang!, which has run in various forms in many theaters throughout New York. The video uses photographs of the puppets from the shows along with collage-style animation to show the drunken heroes braving a storm at sea.
vid: Roving - Jollyship The Whiz-Bang from Andy Wallace on Vimeo.

name: Andy Wallace
description:
Andy Wallace is an independent game designer and creative coder who lives in NYC. He is also a founding member of the non-profit Death By Audio Arcade collective. He received his MFA from Parsons The New School For Design in 2012, and worked for a few years at the tiny NYC game company Golden Ruby Games. After that, he was the director of the Digital Game Design & Development program at Long Island University Post Campus. And now he is available to work on your projects!

He started coding on his parents' IBM 386 when he was 10, and shows no signs of stopping anytime soon. He loves using computers to make magic. If you have freelance inquiries or just want to say hi, he can be reached at andy@andymakes.com or @andy_makes. I'm sure he'd love to hear from you.

His work has been featured on Gamastutra.com, IndieGames.com, Engadget.com, PC World, and CreativeApplications.net among others. His work has been shown througout the world at places like IndieCade, The Smithsonian American Museum Of Art, The Dublin Science Gallery, SF MoMA, MAGfest, The Busan Indie Connection Festival in Korea, and The Museum of The Moving Image.

You can view my CV here.
